ETYMOLOGY: From Old English cēace 'jaw, jawbone'; of Germanic origin; related to Dutch kaak and German Kiefer 'jaw'.

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Either side of the face below the eye and above the mouth.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: She gently stroked the baby's soft cheek.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 她轻轻抚摸着婴儿柔软的脸颊。

MEANINGS.PATTERN: have the cheek to do [sth] | what a cheek!
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He had the cheek to ask for a pay rise after being late all week.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他竟然敢在一周都迟到后要求加薪，真是厚颜无耻。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Each of the two fleshy halves of the buttocks.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The toddler fell, landing hard on his cheeks.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 那个蹒跚学步的孩子摔倒了，重重地坐在了屁股上。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To speak impudently or disrespectfully to someone.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Don't you dare cheek your elders like that!
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 你胆敢那样顶撞你的长辈！

REGISTER: General, with some meanings being informal or colloquial.
